article.titel: Agricultural districts and conservation easements: voluntary agreements to keep America's farmland in agricultural use
article.inleiding: The vulnerability of the world's agricultural land resources has led to the implementation of a number of programs designed to protect valuable agricultural land from unnecessary conversion to nonagricultural uses, to protect especially fragile land from a gradual loss of productivity through erosion and other causes, or to retain the nature and landscape values that inhere in some land used for farming. Continued attention to these programs remains important, even in the face of surplus production of farm products in the European Community, the United States, and elsewhere. The quantity of agricultural land is finite, and that land will continue to be an essential component in the production of food and fiber. Moreover, many of the natural values connected with agricultural land will be lost permanently, without protection. The nature of the programs to protect agricultural land varies from nation to nation (and even in states or other governmental subdivisions within a nation), depending in part on the amount of productive agricultural land, the severity of threats to that land, the legal mechanisms available to mitigate those threats, and public and governmental attitudes towards farmland. The Netherlands has demonstrated an unusual commitment to agricultural land. Because its dense population and intensive agriculturel industry require optimal use of limited land resources, The Netherlands has adopted relatively stringent measures to control and allocate the consumption of its land. Comprehensive physical planning, governed by the Wet op de ruimtelijke ordening, demonstrates a national commitment to sound planning and management in rural areas. Bestemmingsplannen provide the opportunity for municipalities to allocate land for continued agricultural or nature protection uses. Development of polders, most notably through the IJsselmeer project, has resulted in significant additions to the amount of productive agricultural land. And landinrichting, involving rationalization of land ownership patterns as well as other improvements in farm conditions, attempts to improve agriculture structure, while at the same time recognizing other important claims on rural areas. Moreover, special programs (for example, the implementation of Relatienota policy through management agreements) and laws are available to protect nature and landscape values, including important habitats for flora and fauna. It is evident that most of the Dutch programs affecting agricultural land involve the national government in some significant way.
article.content: In contrast, in the United States, issues concerning land use have traditionally been within the legislative competence of state, rather than federal, government.1 Thus, many (though certainly not all) of the most significant legislative measures connected with the protection of agricultural land have been enacted by state governments or by local governments pursuant to power delegated by the states. Legislation preserving agricultural land in the United States is often directed toward the broad goal of protecting prime and otherwise unique farmland from unnecessary conversion to nonagricultural uses. Sometimes, however, individual legislative schemes demonstrate more specific goals; these suggest that agricultural land protection in the U.S. has both long-term and short-term components.2 One objective of agricultural land preservation is to provide for orderly development in urban fringe areas; that is, to avoid the premature departure of agricultural operations from areas not yet ripe for development. This approach reduces development costs because it helps avoid situations in which productive land is idle and random growth consumes farmland. Legislation with this orderly development objective does not always strive to preserve agricultural land permanently. Another objective is to preserve farmland as a scarce and valuable natural resource essential to succeeding generations. The goal is not merely to postpone conversion to ensure orderly development; instead, legislation reflecting this objective attempts to protect farmland permanently. A further objective sometimes evident in the U.S., as in Holland, is to ensure the continued existence of open space areas in urban settings. Open space enhances the quality of life and adds value to existing urban development. These goals of orderly development, permanent farmland preservation, and open space are pursued through various types of farmland preservation programs. In many parts of the U.S., voluntary programs form the main means of protecting productive farmland from irrevocable development. A number of these provide special benefits and legal protections to owners who keep their land in agricultural use. For example, incentives for farmland preservation offered through legislation include reduced real estate taxes, limited immunity from nuisance suits, and protection from some intrusive municipal ordinances. Some farmland preservation schemes in the U.S., as in The Netherlands, are mandatory. Like ruimtelijke ordening, zoning has the potential to prevent the conversion of farmland to nonagricultural uses. In some localities, municipal or county zoning regulations identify areas for agricultural use. In recent years, exclusive agricultural use zoning (permitting only agricultural uses, with farm dwellings and buildings, of specified land) has received more attention. Nonetheless, zoning is often viewed as a function of municipalities, which (unlike in Holland) do not encompass the surrounding countryside. Thus, large areas of agricultural land are simply not regulated by zoning. Often development in the countryside can occur relatively easily. Two types of farmland protection legislation enacted by American states are particularly interesting, because they involve incentives available for specifically identified parcels of agricultural land. These are commonly referred to as agricultural districts and conservation easements. Both are legislative reflections of state public policy that encourages the retention of farmland in agricultural use, either permanently or for a more limited time period. Each type of program has been enacted in a number of states in an attempt to create land reserves where agriculture is the primary activity. Largely effective on a voluntary basis, each program restricts the land use of participating landowners and in return offers incentives for participation. Agricultural districts are designed to prevent the premature departure of farming from the urban fringe, by offering special protection to farmers who choose to participate. Because the districts are established for specific time periods, they foster the orderly development objective of farmland preservation schemes. Conservation easements and related programs are normally intended to ensure the long-term preservation of farmland. Under these programs, the right to develop the land is separated permanently from ownership. In this way, neither the current owner nor any future owners of the land can convert the property to nonagricultural use. AGRICULTURAL DISTRICTS The purpose of agricultural district (sometimes called agricultural area) legislation is to prevent the premature end of farming on the urban fringe, or in other vulnerable localities, by offering a number of protections to the agricultural operations of farmers in that fringe.3 These protections are intended to offset uncertainties faced by farmers in areas of urban growth and to alleviate problems encountered when the character of the community surrounding farmland changes from rural to urban. 4 By encouraging establishment of districts in which the primary land use is farming, agricultural district legislation also attempts to achieve efficiënt development by directing new growth toward existing vacant parcels instead of toward vulnerable and productive agricultural land. Most of the agricultural district laws effective in American states5 have been enacted since 1965. Although the laws differ from state to state, they tend to follow a rather similar pattern.6 Agricultural districts are formed voluntarily on the initiative of a farmer or group of farmers. Typically, any owner or owners of land may submit a petition to create a district to the local governing body, usually a county authority.7 No land can be included in a district without the owner's consent, and a district must include a minimum number of acres.8 The authority receiving the petition must hold a hearing and act to approve or reject the petition within a limited time period. Once approved, the agricultural district is established for a specified time period (typically ten years). During the time the district exists, agriculture is to be the only (or sometimes the primary) activity conducted on land within the district. Subject to government approval, owners may withdraw land from the district during the period, but the remaining part of the district continues undisturbed. After expiration of the original term, the district may be dissolved completely on request of a portion of the landowners. If there is no request for dissolution, the district continues, again for a limited period of time. To promote the formation of agricultural districts, these laws give special protections to farmers with land in districts. The protections vary from state to state, but several types are typical. For example, farmers in an agricultural district usually receive relief from inflated real property taxes; their land is taxed as if farming were the highest and best use, and the development potential is not taxed.9 In addition, farmers in districts may receive protection from local ordinances that restrict and regulate farming activities and structures. Such ordinances (for example, limiting use of pesticides or establishing other restrictions that hinder farming) are sometimes demanded by urban-minded residents of a formerly rural area. Agricultural district legislation therefore often limits the power of local governments to regulate agriculture within the district, unless the regulation directly affects public health or safety. Further, agricultural district statutes often limit the authority of special purpose districts to impose ad valorem taxes on land within the districts.10 Other protections also sometimes accompany agricultural district status.11 In a few states, a number of these protections are available on an individual, rather than a district, basis. Landowners have the opportunity to sign a contract restricting development for a specified period (often ten years). In exchange, the farmer receives financial benefits, either reduced property taxes or tax credits.12 Though a rather small number of states (roughly a quarter) have agricultural district laws, and many of those are relatively recent, participation has been significant. In New York, the state with the oldest agricultural district law, over eight million acres (3.24 million hectares) of farmland are enrolled in districts. Other state programs are smaller, but in total more than 25 million acres (10.13 million hectares) of farmland are protected through these programs.13 Despite significant benefits and incentives tied to agricultural districts, and notwithstanding the large number of acres currently enrolled, these legal devices do not prevent the ultimate conversion of farmland to nonagricultural uses. Of course, they help to improve the farmer's situation, and thus may encourage the continuation of farming indefinitely. But normally they keep agriculture in place untill the protected land is truly needed for immediate urban growth. Moreover, as the discussion above indicated, participation in agricultural districts is voluntary; owners who are willing to sell their land for development may simply refuse to join a district.14 RESTRICTIONS ON DEVELOPMENT Another type of American legislative scheme is designed to protect farmland over the long term, while at the same time allowing the farmer to maintain a property interest in the land and to pursue normal agricultural activities without restrictions. Such programs limit the farmer's right to convert the land to nonfarm use (for example, commercial development), but leave intact the right to use the property for agricultural purposes. This is accomplished by separating the right to develop the land from the underlying ownership of the land itself. Programs permanently severing the right to develop have various titles, including conservation easements15, land preservation easements, deed restrictions, and purchase of development rights.16 Despite this variety of labels and some differences in the operation of the programs, they share the goal of preserving productive agricultural land and open space for succeeding generations. In essence, these programs authorize purchase of conservation easements or development rights on selected parcels of agricultural land.17 Although the legislative schemes in the various states are not identical, some generalization about their operation is appropriate. Normally, the state legislature creates a committee or other body charged with administration of the development rights program. The body has authority to consider offers from qualified owners who want to sell (or donate) a conservation easement or their development rights. Because the objective is to protect the maximum number of acres of prime farmland with the money available, some state laws include criteria for identifying the parcels of land that are most vulnerable or most valuable and therefore should receive priority for purchase of development rights.18 After the conservation easements or development rights have been acquired pursuant to statute, the legislatively-authorized agency holds those rights and enforces the preservation restrictions. These rights acquired under a state program are normally held in perpetuity19, and the resulting use restrictions bind future owners of the farmland. Conservation easements can be terminated, if at all, only through statutory procedures when the public interest no longer requires restrictions on development. The existence of a conservation easement does not grant right of access or use to the general public. Owners who convey conservation easements or development rights retain title to the land. Farmers may continue to use the property for ordinary agricultural operations, but the land may not be developed. Thus landowners who sell conservation easements realize part of the value of the property (that is, the cash value of development rights or the easement) without sacrificing their means of livelihood. Those who donate, rather than sell, such easements often receive value in the form of a federal income tax deduction. Conservation easements, like agricultural districts, are usually voluntary agreements. Transfer of a conservation easement to the state or another body will occur only if the landowner agrees. Farmers are willing to cooperate because they will receive compensation for surrendering the right to develop.20 The availability of compensation, however, suggests the major difficulty in programs to acquire conservation easements or development rights: the cost. The land most vulnerable to conversion - that is, land with the most potential for development - has the most valuable development rights. Financial constraints thus dictate that these programs can protect only a limited number of acres of productive agricultural land. Despite the desirability and effectiveness of the conservation easement approach, fewer than 100,000 acres (40,500 hectares) have been protected through these government programs. 21 Conservation easements, as described here, must be distinguished from the 'conservation reserve' authorized by the Food Security Act of 1985 and linked with the complicated United States price and income support program for agriculture.22 The conservation reserve is a federal program intended primarily to reduce damage and costs from soil erosion, but also to decrease productive capacity and to support crop prices.23 It will have the additional effect of protecting wildlife by providing protective habitat and reducing the amount of harmful chemicals used on agricultural land. Under this program, producers contract with the U.S. government to retire 'highly erodible' cropland (as defined in implementing regulations) from production for ten years.24 In place of commercial agricultural use of the land, the contracts require the planting of conservation cover on the land. Technical help in this endeavor is available from state and federal agencies. Producers receive annual rental payments for land in the conservation reserve. In addition, they receive cost-share payments for up to 50 percent of the cost of establishing approved vegetative cover or trees on the conservation reserve land. Farmers who return land to production prior to the end of the ten-year contract period must repay rental and cost-share payments with interest. During announced signup periods, interested farmers may submit a bid to enroll land in the reserve. Normally not more than 25 percent of land in any county can be bid into the program; this limitation is designed to avoid adverse effects on local economies. The program may include up to 45 million acres (18.225 million hectares) of eligible cropland by crop year 1990. By October 1987, nearly 23 million acres of land were on contract at average rental payments of $48.40 per acre per year. Estimates suggest that conservation efforts on this land will prevent about 467 million tons of soil erosion annually.25 The conservation reserve is thus more similar than conservation easements to the Dutch beheersovereenkomsten, instruments of Relatienota policy that involve sixyear contracts under which landowners promise to tailor their farming practices to the needs of nature and landscape. Although their purposes are somewhat different, both the conservation reserve and beheersovereenkomsten have the effect of offering protection for natural values. The conservation reserve, however, advances nature values by taking land out of commercial agricultural production, rather than altering farming activities. In addition, both are temporary agreements that leave room for flexibility at the conclusion of the contract period. Because that flexibility allows the protective measures taken under the contract to be terminated, however, it may signal the ultimate failure of the purposes of the agreements. Conservation easements, in contrast, offer more certainty of protection: normally their duration is perpetual. Yet, as societal needs and environmental values change over the years, the permanence of conservation easements may limit land use options by imposing the value judgments of the present on future generations. CONCLUSION Agricultural districts and conservation easements represent only two of the many legal arrangements available in the United States for the protection of farmland. Nonetheless, they are important instruments. Agricultural districts offer incentives that have encouraged widespread participation, and conservation easements promise long-term protection to especially vulnerable land. The voluntary nature of these programs means that only those truly committed to continuation of agricultural use of their land will participate. Although this may limit the amount of land protected, political realities may have dictated this element of voluntary participation. American farmers seem more reluctant than Dutch farmers to accept intrusive government involvement in land-use decisions; thus, mandatory programs face greater obstacles to enactment. These programs are neither as successful as ruimtelijke ordening in avoiding undesirable development, nor as effective as landinrichting in improving the structure of agricultural land. Nonetheless, they represent two of the more successful legal means by which America's fertile agricultural land is kept available to provide food, fiber, and open space.
